data.title: 'Zookeeper,' Kevin James can't corral potential
data.meta_description: Well-meaning, sort of sweet, but can't really get it together: That describes both Kevin James' character and his new movie, "Zookeeper." Which is too bad, because both seem to have a lot of untapped potential.
data.text:
By ,

Well-meaning, sort of sweet, but can't really get it together: That describes both Kevin James' character and his new movie, "Zookeeper."

Which is too bad, because both seem to have a lot of untapped potential.

Directory Frank Coraci, veteran of several Adam Sandler comedies ("The Waterboy," "The Wedding Singer"), steers the humor from the broadly slapstick to the logically absurd and back again. He owes what success he has to James' good-natured, all-in attitude.

James plays a caring, competent zookeeper whose brain is short-circuited when he re-connects with the vapid model who broke his heart five years earlier because his job wasn't impressive enough.

When he considers becoming a high-end car dealer to impress her, the animals break their vow of silence to give him some truly terrible (and often gross) romantic advice.

An impressively random menagerie of celebrities give the animals their voices, including Sandler, Nick Nolte, Maya Rudolph, Judd Apatow, Cher and Sylvester Stallone.

Sandler gets the most laughs with lines that seem ad-libbed around the animals' natural actions, augmented by digitally enhanced mouth movement. You can almost see the five guys who share screenwriting credit - including James - shouting smart-aleck lines at nature film footage of animals and then turning it into a script.

Stallone and Cher get a few chuckles, too. I think they'd make an interesting comic screen couple - in human form.

And Rosario Dawson as the zoo veterinarian in love with James - did I mention absurd? - is a welcome comedic surprise.

Less successful are a ridiculous gorilla field trip to T.G.I. Friday's and a pointless and dark subplot about animal abuse by fellow zookeeper Donnie Wahlberg, who pops up infrequently but still too often.

Resist the temptation to bolt from this ultimately disappointing movie: The outtakes over the closing credits are the funniest part.

Zookeeper **
